chapters.content:
Chapter 1 covers the installation, operation, and types of water heaters and combination systems. Tankless water heaters are available in three main types: indoor power vent (uses fan to push flue gases, combustion air from inside space), indoor direct vent (combustion air from outdoors to sealed chamber, two pipes or concentric pipe through wall/roof), and outdoor (combustion air from immediate environment). Indoor units are Category 3 or Category 4 appliances with positive vent static pressure, utilizing stainless steel or plastic venting. Venting systems must be sized and installed per manufacturer literature with minimum number of fittings, and terminations per manufacturer, local codes, and CSA B149.1.

Removal and installation procedures are performed in three stages: obtaining permits, removal (shutdown/disconnection/removal of old unit), and installation (installation/start-up/adjustment of replacement unit). The removal procedure includes turning off gas and cold-water supply, opening hot-water faucet and drain valve, allowing heater to cool, disconnecting gas supply piping, disconnecting plumbing piping when drained, and removing heater.

Installation must be per manufacturer instructions and all applicable codes, referring to Clause 7.27 of CSA B149.1. Unless direct-vent type, water heaters shall not be installed in bedrooms, bathrooms, or sleeping areas. Installation clearances for underfired storage-type must be minimum 2 in (50 mm) at rear and sides, with ample clearance at front for lighting, servicing, cleaning, and adjustment. Drain valve, thermostat, and burners must be accessible for removal.

Combustion air and venting requirements include adequate ventilation for oxygen consumption. For naturally-drafted units (except direct-vent), if installed in enclosed area, ventilation openings or air inlet must be provided per code. When water heater is used in combo heating system (except direct-vent), return-air inlets shall not be installed in same enclosure containing both air-handling unit and water heater. Return air ducts must be sealed to prevent infiltration from enclosure.

Draft hood must be installed without alteration with relief openings unobstructed. Vent pipe run should be short with slight upward slope and few elbows. Clearances to combustible surfaces: single-wall vent 6 in (150 mm), Type B vent 1 in (25 mm), Type BH per venting manufacturer, sides of water heater at least 2 in (50 mm).

Water heater should not be installed where water damage can result from leakage (especially multi-storey buildings). Installation must include means of directing leakage to suitable drain via pan. If supply water pressure exceeds code maximum or working pressure of tank, pressure-reducing valve must be installed on inlet supply line.

Water-piping installation includes leveling heater, closing main water supply, releasing pressure and draining by opening faucets, installing fittings for cold/hot connections (markings identify inlet/outlet), checking cold-water inlet contains factory-furnished dip tube, and not soldering supply pipe directly to cold-water inlet. Cold-water inlet line must contain shut-off valve with union provided. NPC requires vacuum-relief valve in cold-water supply line between shut-off valve and cold-water inlet to prevent vacuum from imploding tank (storage tanks susceptible to external pressures, may collapse if internal pressure drops below 0 psig). If plastic piping used for water distribution, manufacturers recommend not connecting within 18 in (450 mm) of water heater; use minimum 18 in metallic piping.

Gas-piping installation per CSA B149.1 for type and size. Rating plate indicates gas type and maximum rated input. Remove burrs, oil, pipe compound, and contamination from pipe interior (foreign material can damage gas-control valve). Cut piping per good practices, ensure all connections gas-tight, avoid stressing gas control valve by supporting with wrench when attaching supply pipe. Slowly open gas shut-off valve and check all gas piping (including factory piping) for leaks using appropriate liquid solution or leak-detection device.

Venting installation per Clause 8 of CSA B149.1 and manufacturer instructions. Filling procedure: close drain valve, open cold-water supply valve, open nearby hot-water faucet (remove aerator to avoid clogging) to allow air to escape, when steady stream flows tank is full, close faucet and replace aerator, check all water piping for leaks.

Installation checklist includes gas leak check (turn on main gas supply, relight other pilots, turn on heater shut-off valve, do not light pilot, do not use match or open flame, use liquid solution or leak-detection device, apply soap mixture to all joints, observe for soap bubbles indicating leaks, repair as necessary) and general installation check (at least 2 in clearance to combustibles, no water leakage, adequate ventilation, heater completely filled with all air expelled, gas piping conforms to codes, draft hood and vent pipe properly installed).

Pilot lighting instructions typically include turning pilot on-off dial to off, waiting five minutes when relighting, turning dial to pilot position, applying open flame to pilot opening and depressing pilot reset button for one minute until flame remains constant, turning dial to on position, and adjusting thermostat to desired temperature.

Direct-fired storage heaters are most common for residential and low-demand commercial installations. Indirect-fired systems heat stored water using secondary heat-transfer fluid. Direct-fired storage heaters heat water via gas flame's hot products of combustion. Tankless water heaters provide water heated on demand, less space required, and greater efficiency (but not operation at lower firing rates). Not all fin-tube boilers suitable for heating potable water.

Direct-vent water heaters differentiated by combustion air vented directly to unit from outdoors. Power-vent water heaters use motor-driven fan to remove products of combustion. Intermittent pilot used with power-vented units. Plastic venting material must meet ULC S636 standard. Condensing water heaters achieve high efficiencies by capturing latent heat.

Combination systems provide domestic water heating and space heating. Water should be stored at minimum 140 °F (60 °C) to eliminate Legionella bacteria growth. At 140 °F, third-degree burn occurs in 4 seconds. Rod and tube aquastat maintains typical differential of 10 to 15 °F. ECO stands for Energy cut-off. FVIR (Flammable Vapour Ignition Resistant) technology makes residential storage-type heaters more resistant to accidents from mishandling gasoline or flammable materials. Pumps for circulating domestic (potable) water must be stainless steel or bronze. When connecting to water heater, minimum 18 in (450 mm) metallic piping should be installed before connecting to plastic water distribution piping.

chapters.content:
Chapter 2 covers temperature and flow control devices used in combination heating systems. Closed-loop systems use non-potable water as heat transfer medium that cannot be released to atmosphere by opening faucet. Open systems have contact with atmosphere at some point.

Temperature and flow-control devices include properly sized temperature and pressure-relief valve, expansion tank, check valve, vacuum-relief valve, mixing valve, circulating pump, and approved backflow preventer (in closed systems).

Temperature and pressure-relief valve (T&P) is code requirement for all plumbing systems. T&P valve opens to safely discharge fluid before excessive pressures develop. Expansion tank contains increased volume of fluid when heated. Diaphragm-type expansion tank has internal diaphragm dividing tank into two chambers: lower chamber contains compressed air pre-pressurized by manufacturer (must be adjusted to match system-design pressure), upper chamber accommodates expanded volume of heated system fluid. Fluid entering tank causes diaphragm to flex, further compressing air in lower chamber. When fluid volume reduces due to cooling, fluid in expansion tank forced back into system by pressure exerted on diaphragm by compressed air.

Check valves prevent reverse flow but should not be confused with or substituted for approved backflow prevention assemblies (not designed or approved for cross-contamination prevention, backflow-prevention assemblies more elaborate, often require annual testing and maintenance). Most common type is swing check valve with hinged disc that swings open to allow flow in desired direction (works best in upright horizontal position only). Vertical check valve commonly called lift check. Other types incorporate spring and can be installed in any position. When fluid flow reverses, disc closes onto valve seat preventing backwards flow.

Vacuum-relief valves are normally open valves installed on cold-water inlet lines to storage tanks. Not a backflow device - purpose is to allow air to enter water system to prevent negative pressure in water heater storage tank. Any vacuum created opens vacuum-relief valve to draw in outside air to maintain pressure balance. At atmospheric pressure, water boils at 212 °F (100 °C); if pressure lower than atmospheric (as in vacuum), it boils and changes state to steam at lower temperature.

Mixing valve is thermostatic type used to blend cold water with hot water from tank to achieve lower temperature for domestic use. Circulating pump (circulator) moves fluid through hydronic system. Centrifugal-type pump most commonly used. Circulation pump control may be simple on-off switch for domestic hot water recirculating system or relay-type device. Relay operation: on call for heat, thermostat contacts close energizing coil of 24-V relay, normally open contacts of relay close to complete 110-V pump operating circuit; when desired temperature reached, thermostat contacts open, relay contacts open, and pump stops.

Additional requirements include no chemical additives in system, no water heater to replace existing boiler, water conditioning may be required in hard-water areas, backflow preventer required wherever potential for cross-contamination of potable and non-potable systems exists. Qualified installer/tester must install vacuum-relief valve and ensure provisions alleviate potential for bacterial growth within potable water system.

System layouts show combination systems with storage-type water heater and tankless water heater for domestic water and fan-coil space heating. Notes specify all piping and components approved for potable use, all copper tubing type K or L, all plastic piping approved for potable use, if hot water above 140 °F (60 °C) mixing valve conforming to CSA B125.3 required to supply domestic hot water at 140 °F, for single or multiple space heating units/zones/loops cycle timer must circulate all water in space heating system once every 24 hours, other accessories or components may be used for different controls or required per local codes.

Storage-type system includes hot water supply, cold water supply, return water, fan coil unit with hot water coil and hot water pump with cycle timer, thermometer, CGA approved combo hot water heater, connections for space heating for water heaters without side tappings (note: many municipalities do not allow optional piping method), water heater with side tappings for space heating, check valves, hot supply air duct for space heating, return air duct.

Tankless system includes tankless water heater, hot water supply, cold water supply, return water, fan coil unit with hot water coil and hot water pump with cycle timer, thermometer, domestic hot water 140 °F (60 °C), optional hot water storage tank, space heating thermostat, check valve, bronze body recirculating pump for storage tank with internal check valves, hot supply air duct, return air duct.

Wiring procedures for combination systems per manufacturer instructions and wiring diagrams. Wiring covered in detail in Hydronic heating systems unit. Low-voltage connections made to low-voltage wiring harness. Use insulated butt splices instead of wire nuts for neater, more reliable connections for low-voltage devices such as thermostats.

chapters.content:
Chapter 3 covers systems sizing for water heaters and combination systems. Gas technicians do not design potable water systems (typically plumbers' work), but when sizing domestic hot-water heaters and allowing for combination system requirements, must consider several factors to ensure application needs are met. Important design considerations include accurate calculation of space-heating heat-loss requirements and proper sizing of water heaters and pumps.

Water heater sizing information is basic guide for combination potable-water heating and space-heating applications. Each building's domestic hot-water requirements vary. Proper sizing considers capacity of water heater in gallons and Btu input of water heater.

Determining water heater capacity uses minimum 40 imp gal/48 US gal (180 L) featuring high-recovery or high-efficiency gas-fired water heater. Table 3-1 indicates air handler and water heater combinations adequate for most areas: 600-800 CFM (280-380 L/sec) requires 40 imp gal/48 US gal (180 L); 1000-1200 CFM (470-570 L/sec) requires 50 imp gal/60 US gal (225 L); 1400-1600 CFM (660-755 L/sec) requires two 40 imp gal (180 L) twinned, or one high-input 50 imp gal (225 L), or one 72-75 imp gal/90 US gal (327-341 L); 2000 CFM (940 L/sec) requires any combination having at least 105 000 Btu/h (30.8 kW) output.

Determining water heater input based on calculated heat loss of building and water heater recovery efficiency rating. Perform heat loss calculation per approved industry engineering practices (importance cannot be overstated). Local climate and temperature variations influence building heat loss and input calculations. Water heater in area with long cold winters requires more energy than one in milder climate. Multiplication factor reflecting local climatic conditions factored into calculation. Always consult local information sources for proper climate multiplication factors. Examples for reference only: mild climates Input = calculated heat loss × 1.51, colder climates Input = calculated heat loss × 1.58.

Space heating requirements: minimum capacity of appliance or portion used for space heating based on calculated heat loss of building. Where air handler is only heat source, size accordingly. Design and installation per approved industry engineering practices or manuals published by HRAI, American Society of Heating Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE), or Air Conditioning Contractors of America (ACCA).

Select air handler with heating output exceeding calculated space-heating loss of building and cooling coil sized to match outdoor condensing unit. Heating output of air handler or hot-water coil less than hot-water heater. If water heater undersized, heating capacity of air handler less than rated output.

Domestic hot-water heating: minimum capacity of appliance or portion for supplying domestic hot water based on approved industry engineering practices or publication from ASHRAE, HRAI, or American Society of Plumbing Engineers (ASPE).

Combination space and domestic hot-water heating capacities calculated using worksheet "Combo-system HWT/FAN coil sizing". Design and installation per approved industry engineering practices. Designer may use basic drawings in approved publications showing basic principles of proposed combination system. Other accessories or components may be required per local codes.

CSA B149.1 has two stipulations for location and operation of water heater in combo heating system. Clause 7.27.6 (Return and combustion air): Except for direct-vent water heaters, when water heater used in combo heating system, return-air inlets shall not be installed in same enclosure containing both air-handling unit and water heater; adequate combustion air provided for water heater. Clause 7.27.7 (Return air infiltration): When return air duct(s) of air-handling unit in combo heating system installed in enclosure where any spillage-susceptible appliances located, shall be sealed to air-handling unit casing, and joints in ducting sealed to prevent infiltration of air from enclosure into return-air ducting.

Fan-coil combination systems may have storage-type water heater or tankless water heater. Sample combination-system sizing based on dwelling with two bedrooms, two bathrooms, and 21 000 Btu/h heat loss (typical domestic hot water usage rates). If dwelling has additional hot-water requirements (such as hot tub), system must be designed to meet those requirements.

Sample water heater specification: 50 gal (225 L) storage capacity, 50 000 Btu/h (15 kW) input, 76% recovery efficiency, 38 000 Btu/h (11 kW) output. Referring to worksheet, designed domestic draw of 60 gal (273 L) satisfied by selected conventional combination hot-water heater providing 29 700 Btu/h (8.7 kW) for fan coil to meet 24 150 Btu/h (7.1 kW) space heat-loss requirement.

Pump sizing: most combination systems require circulation pump to move water through system. Installation per applicable codes and air handler manufacturer's installation instructions. Circulation pumps should be stainless or bronze-body centrifugal-type pumps designed for hydronic heating systems and sized to meet system requirements. Two factors determine properly sized pump selection: flow rate and pressure loss. After determining system flow rate and pressure loss, use manufacturer's pump performance curve data to select proper circulator. Pump performance curve shows relationship between flow rate and pressure loss. Pump sizing covered in greater detail in Hydronic heating system unit.

Circulators generally sized per rule-of-thumb: flow rate of pump should be one USGPM per 10 000 Btu/h heat output required, allowing 1 ft of friction pressure loss per 40 ft of pipe run.

Flow rate refers to amount of water circulated through system. Determined by heat required and temperature difference between water leaving heater and water returning after releasing heat. Required heat measured in Btu/h per heat-loss calculation for building. Flow rate traditionally measured in USGPM.

Pressure loss: flow of water through piping system must overcome resistance due to friction. Pump must overcome this resistance (pressure loss) to maintain required flow rate. After determining flow rate, piping size, and run length, calculate pressure loss. Pressure loss normally measured in feet of head water column (ft. hd. w.c.). To select appropriate pump, must know how much pressure pump develops for given gpm flow rate. Information found on manufacturers' pump curve charts.

Each pump has own pump curve, although more than one pump model may appear on single chart. All circulator manufacturers publish these curves for circulator models offered. To reduce number of circulator models needed while covering wide range of performance requirements, most manufacturers offer circulators capable of operating at three different speeds. Desired speed selected using external switch on circulator's junction box. Each operating speed has corresponding pump curve.

Chapter 4 covers troubleshooting and servicing of water heaters and combination systems. All tankless water heaters have flow switch or flow sensor in cold-water supply. Purpose is to ensure sufficient water flow to appliance to prevent damage. Depending on make and model, flow rate to activate flow switch can be as low as 0.4 USGPM (1.5 L/min) or as high as 0.9 USGPM (3.4 L/min).

To test flow switch, check switch closes contacts at minimum flow rate per manufacturer literature by viewing display screen if model displays flow rates or performing flow test and slowly opening hot water faucet. Flow test procedure: use graduated container and time fill rate, once minimum flow rate established ensure sufficient voltage at both terminals of flow switch (consult manufacturer as voltage can be AC or DC depending on make and model), if voltage correct de-energize appliance and test resistance through flow switch by disconnecting wires and connecting ohmmeter (should be no resistance through switch when water flowing).

Non-electrical problems and servicing: gas manifold pressure problems can lead to stacking, poor burner flame, and condensation, which cause further problems. Use manometer to check manifold pressure (U-tube type and digital manometers most accurate). Rating plate lists correct manifold pressure. Connect manometer to manifold for pressure test.

Main gas pressure regulator forms part of water heater control unit, adjusted per manufacturer specifications at factory. Adjustment screw in centre of control unit dial. Some control units have sealed adjustment (not possible to change; if out of calibration, replace). If adjustable, remove regulator adjustment screw cap by inserting screwdriver into screw slot rotating counterclockwise, use small screwdriver to remove sealant from adjustment screw top, connect manometer to test outlet of control unit, with burner operating adjust gas pressure as necessary (turn adjustment screw clockwise to increase pressure, counterclockwise to decrease), replace adjustment screw cap when finished. If manifold pressure correct and input clocked and incorrect, check if orifice correct size per rating plate. If incorrect size, change it.

Stacking check procedure: turn off cold-water supply, draw small amount of water from drain valve and check/note temperature, turn on cold-water supply, draw water from any hot-water faucet and let run for minute or two then check/note temperature. If temperature difference greater than 25 °F (14 °C), stacking condition exists. Five causes of stacking and corrections: too long dip tube (remove and check length per manufacturer specifications, correct length or replace), excessive liming of tank (covered later), leaky faucets from water tank (repair faucet, leaks may not be visible such as in drain line, remove drain line to check), frequent draws of hot water (limit number of times hot water drawn), repeated short-cycling of control unit (replace control unit).

Removing dip tube method: turn off cold-water supply (do not use any water until repair finished), turn control unit to pilot position, open hot-water faucet and wait for water to stop flowing (very important), close faucet, draw 4-5 buckets of water off system through drain cock, cut copper tubing between shut-off valve and cold-water inlet to tank, remove dip tube, make any soldered connections required on tubing before attaching new or resized dip tube to system, cut dip tube to manufacturer's recommended length or replace with longer one, apply Teflon tape or non-metallic pipe dope to dip tube threads and install in tank, resolder copper (when soldering last joint wrap wet rag around pipe to prevent heat reaching dip tube), turn on cold-water supply, turn on hot-water faucet until water flows continuously, check for water leaks, turn control unit to on position (if replacing anode use same procedure).

Relief-valve discharge: problems causing combination temperature and pressure (T&P) relief valve to discharge include stacking (refer to previous section), too high temperature setting for off position on control unit (recalibrate control unit, if doesn't work replace), control unit sticking in on position (check by rotating dial on and off few times, if sticking in on position replace), lime buildup on T&P relief valve (replace relief valve).

Relief-valve replacement: turn main gas valve off, draw off enough hot water to ensure water at control unit location is cold, turn cold-water inlet valve off, open hot-water faucet until no water flows (very important), close hot-water faucet, apply non-metallic pipe dope to thread of replacement valve, place bucket under point working at to prevent water damage, remove faulty valve, insert new valve into tapping and tighten, turn on cold-water supply, turn on hot-water faucet until water starts to flow, turn on gas and check for leaks, relight pilot and check manifold pressure (also use this method to replace control unit or drain valve).

Low water temperature (not same as lack or absence of hot water): factors and solutions include burner may be clogged (clean burner), orifice may be too small (check recommended size on rating plate and resize), gas pressure may be too low (increase gas pressure), temperature setting on control unit set too low (should have been checked first, increase temperature setting), too many people using water tank (water not getting enough time to reach desired temperature, recommend replace with bigger tank if possible in space), control unit may be out of calibration (check if out, recalibrate per procedure below).

Recalibrating control unit: check calibration by drawing off enough hot water to ensure burner operating, allow thermostat to cycle burner off, manually turn thermostat dial to 130 °F (54 °C) mark, turn off cold-water supply, check hot-water temperature at drain valve. If thermostat more than 20 °F (8 °C) out of calibration, need to recalibrate.

Calibration procedure: turn temperature dial to 130 °F (54 °C) mark (if water temperature so high burner doesn't come on, run enough hot water from faucet to cause thermostat to turn burner on, allow burner to operate until thermostat shuts off), close off cold-water supply, open nearest hot-water faucet to break air lock, slowly open drain valve until flow just sufficient to cover thermometer bulb, wait for temperature on thermometer to stabilize and note, close drain valve, close hot-water faucet and turn cold-water supply back on, turn temperature dial to correspond to measured temperature (note 140 °F mark, each notch on rim of dial corresponds to 10 °F/4 °C in either direction), remove temperature dial and mark location of stop and replace dial (careful not to turn dial when removing and replacing), turn dial clockwise until control snaps on, turn dial counterclockwise slowly until control just snaps off, remove temperature dial while holding stop to prevent rotation and carefully loosen stop adjustment nut, taking care not to move temperature-adjusting screw turn stop until corresponds with reference mark made, replace temperature dial (actual water temperature should now be indicated, good procedure to check water temperature again by repeating steps 2-7).

Check with AHJ for maximum domestic water temperature. At 140 °F (60 °C) water temperature, risk of scalding can occur in less than 5 sec, whereas at 120 °F (49 °C) risk reduced.

Insufficient hot water: some causes same as water not hot enough. Reasons and solutions include temperature dial set below required temperature (set dial to required temperature), control unit out of calibration (recalibrate control unit), manifold pressure lower than rating on plate (adjust manifold pressure), tank excessively limed (replace tank), dip tube broken or cracked (replace dip tube), dip tube installed incorrectly (reinstall dip tube), dip tube has incorrect length (install per manufacturer specifications), heater capacity insufficient for number of people (recommend larger tank), second dip tube installed on hot water outlet (remove this dip tube), hot and cold-water lines crossed (repipe these lines), main burner flame dirty or carboned (clean burner or correct venting and gas-input deficiencies by adjusting gas pressure or orifice size, may also need to clean orifice), heat loss from long runs of uninsulated pipe (insulate long runs), differential on control unit out of range (replace control unit).

Venting spillage of fumes can result from problem in venting system. If appliance naturally drafted, check: draft hood required and in place (if not add to system, ensure not damaged or altered), vent working by ensuring burner on at least 10 min, light smoke generator and hold at draft hood opening (smoke should be drawn into draft hood, if not check for blockage in draft hood and remove, negative pressure in building may also prevent venting due to lack of makeup air), venting pipes may be broken or have too many bends (needs fixing, consult manufacturer literature for correct venting layout), venting system may not be terminated properly leading to positive pressure in vent (may happen only occasionally such as windy days, if problem termination requires fixing), water heater may not be hot enough (warm air unable to rise naturally through system, advise customer to avoid intermittent use of appliance or increase system temperature).

If system temperature must be increased to correct cold flue situation, temperature-control valve may have to be installed. Problems with venting system can be very serious leading to spillage of toxic gases including carbon monoxide. Category 3 and 4 positive-pressure venting systems can also experience venting problems requiring careful consideration for safe installations (covered in detail in Venting practices unit).

Water leaks: ten main areas to check include anode rod fitting (use cotton swab between jacket opening and fitting to wipe area, if leak indicated remove valve and repair with pipe joint compound using same procedure as removing drain valve), draft hood and flue (water can be result of rainwater leaking in, also check for condensation which may cause further problems), piping connections and fittings (if leak turn off water and gas supplies and drain tank properly, disconnect piping, apply pipe joint compound, and replace), drain valve outlet (leak can be from bad gasket, loose packing nut, or valve slightly open, tighten handle first, if persists valve faulty and needs replacement similar to T&P relief valve except must completely drain tank), drain valve at tank (insert cotton swab between jacket opening and fitting to wipe area), water at relief outlet of T&P relief valve (often results from T&P relief valve operating properly, may also be dirt on valve seat needing cleaning, if valve not piped to open drain water can be mistaken for leaking heater), water pipe (often condensation and dripping water seen on pipes in humid weather not result of leak, if pipes leaking need fixing or replacement), heater bottom and floor (if water first check all possible leaking devices such as humidifiers then check for leaking water lines and ground seepage, water may also be result of condensation, loose connections, or relief valve, must find cause before replacing heater), combustion chamber (water usually result of condensation of flue gases, not leak).

Analyzing malfunctions: condensation (scaling or corrosion indicator of condensation forming). Causes of unwanted condensation and resolutions: manifold pressure too low (check manifold pressure, if measured pressure lower than stated on rating plate adjust), main burner orifice blocked or smaller than recommended size (if blocked clean, check recommended size on rating plate, if smaller install correct-sized orifice), flue has obstruction (if found remove, ensure draft adequate and perform flue-gas analysis). When storage-type water heater initially activated and water in tank cold, condensation may form, but once most water heated condensation should cease.

Liming: water contains impurities. As more heat applied, more minerals (calcium and magnesium) removed from water. Minerals build up as calcium carbonate (limescale) on tank bottom. Buildup acts as insulator and reduces efficiency causing higher stack (vent) temperatures. One sign of liming is rumbling and crackling noise from tank caused by water penetrating limescale layer and meeting hot surface (small amounts of water heat quickly and flash to steam, small "explosion" causes rumbling and crackling sound). Water softener can prevent limescale formation (reduces hardness minerals in water).

Measures to resolve lime buildup: if lime buildup not excessive can clean, if tank excessively limed must replace. Deliming procedure: shut off power, gas, and water supply to tank, completely drain tank, remove drain valve and install 6-in nipple in place, remove anode, if no other apparent opening remove either hot or cold-water nipple, use small pressure washer to flush out as much scale and lime as possible by inserting through one hole and shining light through other hole to see, once removed as much as possible plug nipple at drain valve and add muriatic acid or pickling vinegar to tank and allow to stand, after deliming solution stood unplug nipple and allow tank to drain, use pressure washer again to flush tank (as drain about one inch off tank bottom cannot get all lime out but should get most), once finished washing flush tank with 3-5 gallons water to remove all traces of deliming solution, replace drain valve, anode, and any other removed parts, turn on water, fill tank with water, turn on power and gas, start water heater, remove faucet aerators, flush out hot-water lines, replace faucet aerators.

Corrosion: use anode to prevent corrosion in tank. If tank corroding, possible that water softener with incorrect pH added to tank (removing too many impurities, must replace with water softener with correct pH) or anode not working (need to replace). Flue and vent system may also experience corrosion. If air for combustion contains certain chemical vapours that break down into acids during combustion process and bond with water vapour of fuel gas, these acids corrode flue and vent systems. Common chemicals: spray-can repellents, cleaning solvents, bleaches, refrigerants, swimming pool chemicals, calcium, sodium chloride (salt), waxes, and process chemicals. Make every effort to prevent these substances from contacting flue and vent system or air for combustion.

Production of carbon monoxide: carbon monoxide is colourless toxic gas. If inhaled in high enough concentration can cause death. One problem is invisible with no taste or odour, extremely hard to detect. Most common circumstance of carbon monoxide formation is when insufficient oxygen to completely burn fuel gas, leaving some fuel in flue gas. Figure 4-12 shows simple diagram of incomplete combustion forming carbon monoxide.

Another circumstance leading to carbon monoxide formation is when combustion temperature of fuel gas too low. For natural gas, combustion process must maintain temperature of approximately 1200 °F (649 °C). If flame quenched below that temperature (e.g., cooled due to too much excess air or contact with cooler surface), results in incomplete combustion and production of carbon monoxide.

If venting blocked in any way or gases not properly vented, flue gases unable to reach outdoors and remain in room. Flue gas spillage can recirculate through combustion chamber resulting in lack of combustion air. There is incomplete combustion of fuel gas and thus further buildup of carbon monoxide (problems with venting systems discussed earlier). Improperly vented appliance requires immediate correction to venting system, or appliance needs decommissioning, replacing (or both).

Assignment questions cover electrical testing: thermocouple open-circuit test expected reading 30 mV, thermocouple must deenergize pilotstat coil within 60 seconds, water heater equipped with ECO activates when temperature exceeds 200 °F (94 °C), water heaters equipped with rod-and-tube-type thermostatic gas controls have TCO and ECO wired in series with safety shut-off valve, closed-limit switch should have no resistance, to determine integrity of flammable vapour sensor measure resistance, if temperature of NTC thermistor decreases its resistance increases, to ensure adequate (minimum) flow of water through heat exchanger tankless water heaters use flow sensor, to measure manifold pressure use manometer, hardness contributes to lime scale formation, muriatic acid used to remove limescale.

CSA Unit 18 - Water Heaters 
and Combination Systems 
Chapter 1
Installation of new and replacement gas water heaters is a normal part of 
a gas technician's/fitter's duties. The types of heaters, controls, 
components, and piping systems vary greatly as do the installation 
requirements for each type. It is important for the gas technician/fitter to 
be able to identify and select the proper water heater and related 
equipment required for an application and perform the work in 
accordance with applicable Codes and manufacturer's instructions.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Installation Requirements
CSA B149.1
The Natural Gas and 
Propane Installation Code 
specifies requirements for 
water heaters in Clause 7 
(Installation of specific 
types of appliances) and 
Clause 8 (Venting systems 
and air supply for 
appliances).
National Plumbing 
Code of Canada
The NPC specifies the 
requirements for hot water 
tank installations, 
particularly regarding shut-
off valves, relief valves, and 
thermal expansion.
Manufacturer's Instructions
Compliance with manufacturer's recommendations and 
instructions is a code requirement and is necessary for safe and 
efficient water heater installation and servicing.
Code Requirements for Water Heaters
Location Requirements
A water heater, unless of the direct-vent 
type, shall not be installed in a 
bathroom, bedroom, or any enclosure 
where sleeping accommodation is 
provided.
Relief Valve Requirements
The temperature and pressure relief 
device on a tank type water heater shall 
have a discharge pipe of a size at least 
equal to the nominal size of the device 
outlet. The discharge pipe shall 
terminate not more than 12 in (300 mm) 
above the floor.
Clearance Requirements
The minimum clearance from 
combustible material for an underfired 
storage-type water heater shall be 2 in 
(50 mm), and the minimum clearance 
for any other type of water heater shall 
be 6 in (150 mm).
Air Supply Requirements
Small Water Heaters
An outdoor air supply shall not be required for a single water heater with an input of 50,000 Btuh (15 kW) or less within an 
enclosure or structure where there are no other appliances that require an air supply.
Enclosed Heaters
When an appliance is located within an enclosure, permanent openings must be provided to allow communication 
between the enclosure and the rest of the structure.
Opening Size
An opening shall have a free area of not less than 1 in² per 1000 Btu/h (2225 mm² per kW) of the total input of all 
appliances within the enclosure.
Opening Location
The opening shall be located not more than 18 in (450 mm) or less than 6 in (150 mm) above floor level.
National Plumbing Code Requirements
Clause 2.6.1.3 (7)
Every pipe that supplies water to a hot water tank shall be 
provided with a shut-off valve located close to the tank.
Clause 2.6.1.7 (1)
A storage-type service water heater must be equipped with a 
pressure relief valve designed to open when the water pressure in 
the tank reaches the rated working pressure.
Clause 2.6.1.7 (2)
Storage-type service water heaters must be equipped with a 
temperature relief valve with a temperature sensing element 
located within the top 150 mm of the tank.
Clause 2.6.1.7 (3)
A pressure-relief valve and temperature-relief valve may be 
combined (commonly referred to as a "T & P" Valve).
Clause 2.6.1.7 (7)
A shut-off valve is not permitted on the pipe between any tank 
and the relief valves or on the discharge lines from such relief 
valves.
Types of Water Heaters
Direct-Fired Heaters
Heat from the gas flame's hot products 
of combustion are in direct contact with 
a tank or pipe containing the water to be 
heated.
Indirect Water Heating
Heat from the gas flame's hot products 
of combustion does not heat the water 
directly. A fluid (heat transfer fluid) 
heated by a secondary appliance heats 
the stored water.
Under-Fired Storage
The most common type of gas-fired 
water heater, where the burner, storage 
tank, outer jacket, insulation, and 
controls are combined into one unit.
Tankless (On-Demand)
These appliances heat water on demand 
instead of storing heated water in a tank, 
offering continuous hot water supply 
within their rated capacity.
More Water Heater Types
Direct-Vent
Combustion air is supplied directly from the outdoors by enclosed ductwork 
connected directly to the heater. The heater's combustion products are also 
vented directly to the outdoors.
Power-Vented
Used for installations where higher efficiencies are desired or when adequate 
vertical venting through a chimney or B vent is impractical. An electric motor-
driven exhaust fan is typically connected to a certified venting system.
Condensing
Designed to achieve very high levels of thermal efficiency by reclaiming latent 
heat, allowing these appliances to achieve efficiencies well over 90%.
Combination Units
Designed to provide both domestic water heating and space heating, consisting 
of a heat source, space heating unit, circulating equipment, and control devices.
Under-Fired Storage Water Heaters
Construction
In a direct-fired storage heater, the gas flame's hot products 
of combustion heat the water by conduction through the 
tank bottom and flue surfaces. The flue acts as a heat 
exchanger and as a vent for the products of combustion.
Features
•
Most common type of gas-fired water heater
•
Burner, storage tank, outer jacket, insulation, and 
controls combined into one unit
•
Storage tank serves as a heat exchanger
•
Typically available in sizes up to 75 US gallons (300 L) for 
residential use
Tankless (On-Demand) Water 
Heaters
Operation Sequence
When a hot water tap is opened, water flow through the tankless water heater detects 
the call for hot water.
Control Response
The water flow sensor sends a signal to the control board, which monitors incoming 
water temperature, desired water temperature, and the calculated difference 
between the two.
Heating Process
The gas flow into the burner assembly is modulated, the electronic ignition 
sequence begins, and water is heated to the desired temperature as it circulates 
through the heat exchanger.
Shutdown
When the hot water tap is turned off, the tankless water heater sequentially 
shuts down and is placed in a standby mode pending the next call for hot 
water.
Tankless Water Heater Benefits
Energy Efficiency
They have the potential to be 25-30% more energy efficient than storage 
heaters.
Longer Lifespan
Working life has the potential to be longer than a tank-type hot water heater, 
and they are repairable.
Continuous Hot Water
They provide a continuous supply of hot water within their design capacity.
Space Saving
They take up less space and can be wall mounted.
Tankless Water Heater Considerations
Flow Rate Limitations
On-demand production of hot water directly depends on 
the temperature rise required for the installation. The colder 
the inlet water temperature from the source, the lower the 
rate of production available from tankless water heaters.
For example, a 70°F water temperature rise may be possible 
at a flow rate of 5 gallons per minute. Higher flow rates or 
colder groundwater temperatures require higher input 
capacity water heaters.
Gas Supply Requirements
Tankless water heaters have a very high firing rate (normally 
100,000 to 200,000 Btu/h) compared to under-fired 
storage water heaters (normally 35,000 to 80,000 Btu/h). 
As a result, the size of gas pipe to a tankless water heater is 
typically larger.
Proper sizing of gas lines is critical for ensuring adequate 
performance of tankless units.
Copper-Fin-Tube Water Heaters
Description
Copper-fin-tube water heaters used for direct heating or 
copper-fin-tube boilers with separate storage tanks can be 
used in residential, commercial, and industrial applications. 
They require certification as a water heater as they will be 
heating potable water.
Construction
This type of heater consists of a copper-fin-tube heat 
exchanger, enclosed in an insulated sheet-metal outer 
casing. Cold water enters the heat exchanger coil through 
an inlet port, is heated, and may be stored for later use.
Direct-Vent Water Heaters
Combustion Air Supply
A direct-vent water heater's combustion air is supplied 
directly from the outdoors by enclosed ductwork connected 
directly to the heater. The heater's combustion products are 
also vented directly to the outdoors.
Venting Configurations
•
Concentric (coaxial) venting system with a smaller-
diameter duct centrally located in the larger 
combustion-air intake duct
•
Two separate pipes: one for combustion air intake and 
another for flue gas venting
Ensuring adequate and secure venting is of primary 
importance for direct-vent installations.
Power-Vented Water Heaters
Applications
Used for installations where higher efficiencies are desired, when adequate vertical venting through a chimney or B vent is 
impractical, or when the heater location makes power venting necessary.
Construction
An electric motor-driven exhaust fan, mounted on top of the water heater, is typically connected to a certified ULC S636 plastic 
venting system, which conveys the products of combustion to the outdoors.
Operation
The pressure created by the fan induces a draft that pulls dilution air into the draft control openings at the top of the heater. The gas 
valve is interlocked to a differential pressure switch that verifies the venter fan's operation before allowing the gas valve to open.
Ignition System
Standing pilots are not used on these types of water heaters because it comes with a mechanical venting system. Intermittent pilot 
systems or electronic direct ignition systems light the main burner.
Power-Vented Installation Requirements
Must Do
•
Use ULC S636 plastic gas vent pipe as required by Clause 
8.9.6 of CSA B149.1
•
Ensure the venting system services the water heater only
•
Terminate venting in a horizontal run to the outdoors
•
Secure vertical and horizontal piping runs to the building

• describe installation requirements for water heaters;
• describe types of water heaters;

7.27 Water heaters
7.27.1
A water heater, unless of the direct-vent type, shall not be installed in a bathroom, bedroom, or
any enclosure where sleeping accommodation is provided.
7.27.2
The temperature and pressure relief device on a tank type water heater or the pressure relief

size at least equal to the nominal size of the device outlet. The discharge pipe shall terminate
not more than 12 in (300 mm) above the floor.
7.27.3

for an underfired storage-type water heater shall be 2 in (50 mm), and the minimum clearance
for any other type of water heater shall be 6 in (150 mm). See also Clause 4.14.2.
7.27.5
Before installing an instantaneous-type (tankless) water heater, the installer shall ensure that
there is sufficient water supply for proper operation of the heater.
7.27.6

return-air inlets shall not be installed in the same enclosure that contains both an air-handling
unit and the water heater. Adequate combustion air shall be provided for the water heater.

enclosure in which any spillage-susceptible appliances are located, it shall be sealed to the air
handling unit casing, and joints in the ducting shall be sealed to prevent infiltration of air from
the enclosure into the return-air ducting.

8.1 General
8.1.1
The requirements of Clause 8.2 shall apply to central-heating furnaces, boilers, and hot-water
heaters.
8.1.2
The requirements of Clauses 8.2 to 8.5 shall not apply to a direct-vent appliance.

considered a direct-vent appliance.

in an enclosure, permanent openings shall be provided as described in Clause 8.2.6.

located in accordance with Items (a) and (b) of this Clause are supplied to allow communication
between the enclosure and the rest of the structure, the total volume of the structure may be
used to determine air supply requirements, provided that the structure is not constructed as
described in Clause 8.2.1 (a) and does not comply with Clause 8.2.1 (b). Otherwise, the volume
of the enclosure shall be used. The openings shall be as follows:
a) In all cases, an opening shall be provided that shall
i) have a free area of not less than 1 in2 per 1000 Btu/h (2225 mm2 per kW) of the total
input of all appliances within the enclosure; and
ii) be located not more than 18 in (450 mm) or less than 6 in (150 mm) above floor level.

opening shall be supplied having the same free area as the opening required in Item (a),
and the opening shall be located as near the ceiling as practicable, but in no case lower
than the relief opening of the lowest draft-control

8.18.11
Except as provided in Clause 8.18.13, the minimum clearance of a vent connector of other than
Type B vent material from a combustible wall or partition shall be in accordance with Table 8.6.

8.29.2
A power venter certified for use as an add-on to a water heater may be used on a water heater
that has an input of 50 000 Btu/h ( 15 kW) or less.

The NPC specifies the requirements for hot water tank installations. The areas of most concern

expansion . Read and understand the most updated edition and printing with erratum of the NPC

valve located close to the tank.

distribution system .
Clause 2.6.1.7 (2) Additionally it requires that storage-type service water heaters be
equipped with a temperature relief valve with a temperature sensing

Valve).

2. Combination systems
Overview
Purpose
Most occupied buildings have a supply of domestic hot water and equipment for central heating.
Combining the two systems is sometimes the most economical and efficient way to provide both
services. Because the popularity of this type of system is increasing, the gas technician/fitter
must be able to identify, select, and install components and controls that will ensure both the
domestic hot water and space heating requirements of the system are met.
Objectives
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
• describe installation requirements for combination systems;
• describe types of combination systems;
• describe system layout; and
• describe wiring procedures.
Terminology
Term Abbreviation Definition
(Symbol)
Non-potable Water that is not safe to drink
Potable Water that is safe to drink
Installation requirements
General requirements
Special Note: Connections made to gas appliances that include connections to the potable
water system must meet local, provincial, and municipal code requirements and will typically
fall outside of the scope of a gas technician/fitter's practice in most provinces.
It is the responsibility of the gas technician/fitter to comply with all codes, as well as their local
trade regulations. In most jurisdictions within Canada, the only individual permitted to perform
installation, alteration, or repair on any part of a plumbing system is a licensed Red Seal
Plumber or Registered Plumbing Apprentice.
Several associations across Canada provide guidance regarding the installation of combination
potable water heating and space heating systems. National Resources Canada publishes a
water heater guide that outlines the pros and cons of using combination systems. Many
provinces have issued public information bulletins in an attempt to clarify necessary provisions
for these systems. The Canadian Institute for Plumbing and Heating (CIPH) is an association of
manufacturers that promotes the correct use of certified equipment and supports recognized
industry standards for water heating.
CSA B214 contains minimum requirements for combination heating systems. The certified
combination water heater must be listed and marked to the appropriate ANSI/CSA standard
indicating that it can be used in a dual-purpose application .
The Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Institute of Canada (HRAI) has developed a
resource document of suggested best practice with regards to combination systems. The Unified
Canadian Guideline for Integrated (Combination) Heating Systems could be a valuable resource
for qualified individuals that install combination systems as it summarizes several existing
Standards and Code requirements. Included in the HRAI publication are the following list of
requirements:
• These systems consist of a certified combination storage-type or a certified tankless potable
water heater used in conjunction with a fan -coil (ducted) heating system, hydronic baseboard
system, and/or a hydronic radiant slab heating system, and is intended for space heating
applications of not more than 75 000 Btu/h (22 kW).
• Combination system components must be selected and sized to meet and maintain the total
calculated demands for hot water service and space heating heat loss requirements.
• Domestic water heaters incorporated in combination heating systems must be certified and
labelled as being "Suitable for water (potable) and space heating."
• All components in the combination heating system or on the potable water side of a heat
exchanger shall have a design pressure of not less than 1035 kPa (150 psi) and shall be able
to withstand a continuous water temperature of 71 °C (160°F) and a short-term exposure of 99
°C (210°F).
• Ventilation air, which must be introduced into the building in accordance with the Building
Code, must be heated and this will affect the overall system design.
• Piping and components of the combination system that contain potable water must comply
with the requirements of the applicable local plumbing code, or in its absence, the NPC.
• All appliances, accessories, components, equipment, or materials used in an installation must
be of a type and rating approved for the specific application for which they are used.
• The water heating appliance and the fan coil unit must be certified by an approved agency,
such as CSA Group, and labelled "Suitable for water (potable) and space heating."
• Ferrous materials (those containing iron) must not be used for potable water applications.
• The use of non-potable chemicals is prohibited in potable water systems.
• Combination systems may not be connected to any heating systems or components
previously used for non-potable water heating systems.
• A pump-cycle timer must be installed to circulate all water contained in the fan coil space
heating piping and components at least once every 24 hours. The timer may be factory
installed in the air handling unit.
Qualifications and responsibility
Qualified gas technicians/fitters must complete all installations in a skillful, thorough manner. Pay
careful attention to the mechanical aspects of the work, to the layout of the installation, and
proper instructions to the end-user:
• Gas technicians/fitters performing installation, service, and maintenance work on combination
systems must be properly trained and qualified to do so. All work must be done in accordance
with Trade and Apprenticeship Acts and/or fuel certification licenses applicable to the
jurisdiction in which the work is being performed. For example, in most provinces, any work
beyond the immediate piping of the gas-fired appliance connections are the responsibilities of
a licensed Red Seal Plumber or registered plumbing apprentice.
• The installation technician/fitter must ensure that the appliance, accessory, component, or
equipment installed complies with all Code requirements. The technician/fitter initially
activating the appliance must ensure that it is in safe working order.
• The installer must instruct the end-user in the safe and proper operation of all the appliances
and equipment installed and supply the end-user with the appropriate manufacturer's
operation and maintenance instructions.
Manufacturer's and other design requirements
All appliances, accessories, components, equipment, or any other item must be installed in
accordance with the manufacturer's installation instructions and approved trade practices,
including the following . Where a conflict exists between the manufacturer's installation
instructions and applicable Codes, the Code requirements must be followed, unless otherwise
approved by the authority having jurisdiction (AHJ).
• Existing non-potable hydronic systems, or parts taken from or connected to these systems,
must not be connected to potable water combination systems.
• No chemicals, such as those used in a typical boiler-heated system, may be added to the
combination system.
• Provision must be made to allow the entire combination system to be drained.
• Only potable water may be used to test the combination system, and the system must be
flushed before being put into service.
• All components of the combination system must be installed with provision for ready access
for inspection, maintenance, repair, and cleaning, in accordance with the manufacturer's
operation and maintenance instructions.
• The air conditioning system must be installed in such a manner that any component of the air
conditioning system will not obstruct service or removal of the water heater or other
components.
• The installer must affix a warning label, in plain view of the consumer, which states that the
water temperature controls should not be adjusted or tampered with by the end-user.
Combo performance specification summary
CSA Combo Performance Specification Summary (refer to CAN/CSA P.9) applies to forced-air
combo heating systems. This Standard allows mechanical designers to:
• select and specify an efficiently and appropriately sized combination system; and
• to provide the installer with a table of requirements and selected system ratings and the
manufacturer's P.9 performance summary and system schematic.
It is important to use the CAN/CSA P.9 efficiency ratings as simply knowing the efficiency of a
water heater in water heating mode only does not provide useful information on the efficiency of a
combination system in space heating mode.
The National Building Code of Canada (and some provincial building codes) recently set a
minimum requirement for systems using the CAN/CSA P.9 Thermal Performance Factor {TPF).
TPF defines the gas-use efficiency based on both space and water heating test ratings. Higher
values equate to higher efficiency and lower energy costs. The minimum acceptable TPF may be
set by the building code or in relation to any high-performance housing program that the owner or
builder plans to enroll the home with. For example, ENERGY STAR® for new homes standard
identifies that a water heater be of the condensing type and that the heater has undergone testing
according to the procedures outlined in CAN/CSA P.9 in order to meet their requirements.
Types of combination systems
Combination systems perform two functions:
• space heating; and
• domestic water heating.
System components
To understand the different types of combination systems and their operation, the gas technician/
fitter must have a working knowledge of their components. The components of combination
systems are grouped into four main categories:
• heat sources;
• space heating units;
• circulating equipment; and
• control devices.
Systems and water heaters should be identified and certified as suitable for combination heating
systems.
Principles of operation
In a typical combination system, hot water is drawn from a gas-fired storage-type water heater
and circulated through a water-to-air heat exchanger (fan-coil). The heat exchanger in some
systems is called a fan coil unit. A fan forces the wa

Gas technicians do not design potable water systems as this work is typically done by plumbers.
However, when sizing domestic hot water heaters and allowing for combination system
requirements, the gas technician/fitter must consider several factors to ensure that the needs of
the application are met. Important design considerations include accurate calculation of space
heating heat loss requirements and proper sizing of water heaters and pumps.
Objectives

Be aware that each building's domestic hot water requirements vary. Proper water heater sizing

Determining water heater input
The required water heater input calculation is based on the:
• calculated heat loss of the building in which the system is to be installed; and
• water heater recovery efficiency rating.
Perform the heat loss calculation in accordance with approved industry engineering practices.
The importance of this step cannot be understated.
Local climate and temperature variations have an effect on building heat loss and will therefore
also influence input calculations.
For example, a water heater installed in an area that has long, cold winters would require more
energy to produce a given amount of heat than one installed in a milder climate. For this reason,
a multiplication factor reflecting local climatic conditions must be factored into the calculation .
Always consult local information sources to ensure that your calculations include the proper

Space heating requirements
The minimum capacity of an appliance or the portion of its total capacity used for space heating
must be based on the calculated heat loss of the building. Where an air handler is used as the
only source of heat, it should be sized accordingly. The design and installation of the system must
be in accordance with approved industry engineering practices or manuals published by one of
the following organizations or an equivalent:
• Heating, Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Institute of Canada (HRAI);
• American Society of Heating Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASH RAE); or
• Air Conditioning Contractors of America (ACCA).
Air handler
Select an air handler with a heating output that:
• exceeds the calculated space heating loss of the building; and
• has a cooling coil sized to match the outdoor condensing unit.
The heating output of the air handler or hot water coil will be less than the output of the hot water

The minimum capacity of an appliance, or the portion of its total capacity used for supplying
domestic hot water, must be based on approved industry engineering practices or publication

4. Servicing systems
Overview
Purpose
An important part of a gas technician's/fitter's duties is to solve safely, accurately, and efficiently
the technical problems associated with hot water heating and combination systems. The gas
technician/fitter must know how to troubleshoot and service electrical and non-electrical systems
and components and analyze and correct problems that result from water conditions and
improper combustion.
Objectives
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
• service hot water heater and combination system electrical components;
• troubleshoot and correct water heater and combination system non-electrical problems; and
• analyze water heater and combination system malfunctions that result from water conditions
and combustion problems.
Ter1ninology

Electrical components
The fact that there is no hot water could indicate an electrical problem with the heater.
If the water heater comes with a standing pilot, check if the pilot burner is out. If yes, it could be
due to a number of electrical problems, including:
• loose thermocouple connection to the control unit;
• defective thermocouple; and
• defective pilot magnet (pilotstat coil).
76 September 2020
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 18 Water heaters and combination systems
Testing for a loose thermocouple connection
If the thermocouple connection to the control unit is loose, then tighten it a 1 /4 turn past hand
tight. You can also remove the thermocouple and check the terminal to make sure it is not broken
or cracked . Ensure the threads are in good order.
Testing for a defective thermocouple
To test for a defective thermocouple, use a millivolt-meter or a multi-meter.
The two tests for a fau lty thermocouple are:
• open-circuit test; and
• closed-circuit test.
Open-circuit test
An open-circuit test shows the potential millivolts that a thermocouple can produce when it is not
under load. Perform the test as follows:
1) Disconnect the thermocouple from the pilotstat.
2) Select a scale on the millivolt-meter suitable for reading a maximum of 30 mV.
3) Connect one lead of the meter to the outer copper conductor of the thermocouple and the
other lead to the end of the inner conductor, as shown in Figure 4-1 . With a pilot flame
heating the hot junction of the thermocouple, the meter should read approximately 30 mV.
4) If the meter reading is less than 20 mV, the thermocouple needs replacement.

3) Connect one test lead to the outer conductor of the thermocouple and the other test lead to

Testing for a defective pilotstat coil ( drop-out test)
The third electrical problem could be with the pilotstat coil.
A small current is required in the coil to develop the magnetic field needed to hold the pilotstat
valve open. Because the current is so small, it is easier to test the voltage through the coil. Place
the test adapter as shown in Figure 4-2, and perform the test as follows:
1) Connect one lead of the millivoltmeter to the copper conductor and the other to the terminal
on the side of the test adapter. The normal reading should be between 10 and 15 mV.
2) Blow out the pilot flame and allow the thermocouple to cool. As the thermocouple cools,
observe that the reading on the millivoltmeter slowly decreases.
3) The coil of the pilotstat should create enough magnetic field to hold the valve open until the
millivoltage drops to between 5 and 2 mV.

Testing resistances and the use of the thermopile
Increases in resistance that reduce the current to a point where the gas valve coils do not operate
cause many problems in millivolt control systems. The following cause these increases:
• loose wiring connections;
• corrosion to terminals and connectors;
• poor wire splices; and
• excessive wi re lengths.
The easiest way to identify where increases in resistance have developed is to measure the
millivolt drop across each component in the electrical circuit. Excessive millivolt drop indicates
excessive resistances.
Energy cut-off and thermal cut-off device
An energy cut-off (ECO) device is a safety feature added to many thermostatic gas controls. The
ECO is a fusible link wired in series between the thermocouple and the safety shut-off valve
inside the control valve (Figure 4-3). It monitors the temperature of the water in the tank.
The fuse is either located alongside the invar rod inside the copper tube or is independent of the
temperature control probe. If the temperature of the water exceeds the preset limit (usually 200°F
or 94 °C), the fuse melts and the circuit is broken between the thermocouple and the safety
shutoff valve, and the gas flow to the burner is terminated.
An ECO is a single-use fuse. Once the device is activated, the gas valve must be replaced. If the
pilot burner does not remain lit when the reset button is released, check for continuity through the

A thermal cut-off device acts as limit switch. It monitors the temperature of the combustion
chamber. For example, in FVIR systems when the flame arrestor becomes clogged with lint, dust,
or oil, a temperature sensor will shut down the unit. The thermal limit or thermal cut-off (TCO)
performs two primary functions:
1) In the event of flammable vapour ignition inside the combustion chamber, it senses the
corresponding increase in temperature and shuts off gas flow to the main and pilot burners.
2) If excessive temperatures inside the combustion chamber indicate poor combustion because
of a clogged screen or filter or inadequate air for combustion, the TCO will shut off gas flow
to the main and pilot burners.
The TCO can be mounted just inside the outer door, or it can be part of the pilot assembly.
If the water heater is equipped with a rod-and-tube type thermostatic gas control the TCO is
usually wired in series with the ECO and safety shut-off valve (Figure 4-4 ).

Unit 18-Water Heaters andCombination Systems
Overview
Purpose
Installation of new and replacement gas water heaters form a normal part of your duties as a gas technician/fitter. The types of heater, controls, components and piping systems vary greatly as do the installation requirements for each type. A thorough understanding of gas-fired water heaters and combination system installation, servicing and maintenance will ensure that the hot water requirements are adequate for the building.
Unit 18-Water Heaters and Combination Systems
Objectives
At the end of this unit you will be able to:
Identify and understand the operation of gas-fired water heaters.
Identify and understand the operation of combination systems.
Size and install gas-fired hot water heating and combination systems.
Service hot water heating and combination systems.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
Overview 
Purpose 
Installation of new and replacement gas water heaters is a normal part of a gas technician's/fitter's duties. The types of heaters, controls, components, and piping systems vary greatly, as do the installation requirements for each type. 
It is important for the gas technician/fitter to be able to identify and select the proper water heater and related equipment required for an application and perform the work in accordance with applicable Codes and manufacturer's instructions.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
Objectives 
At the end of this chapter you will be able to: 
•	Describe installation requirements for water heaters.
•	Describe types of water heaters.
•	Describe water heater controls and accessories.
•	Describe water heater piping layout.
•	Describe hot water storage systems.
•	Describe water heater removal and installation procedures.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
Terminology
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
Installation Requirements 
The following Codes specify the requirements for installation of gas-fired water heaters: 
•	Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code, CSA B149.1
•	National Plumbing Code of Canada
Interpret Codes 
The gas technician/fitter is responsible for correctly interpreting and following the relevant Code requirements when installing gas-fired water heaters.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
Natural Gas and Propane Installation Code Requirements 
Two sections of the CSA B149.1 Code specifically address the requirements for water heaters: 



Only those clauses that are specific to water heaters or combination systems are quoted below. Clause 8 should be reviewed in its entirety to determine how other air supply and venting requirements that apply to all appliances are applicable to water heaters and combination systems.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
Section 7-lnstallation of Specific Types of Appliances 
7.27 Water heaters 
7.27.1 
A water heater, unless of the direct-vent type, shall not be installed in a bathroom, bedroom, or any enclosure where sleeping accommodation is provided.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
7.27.2 
The temperature and pressure relief device on a tank type water heater or the pressure relief device provided for an instantaneous (tankless) water heater shall have a discharge pipe of a size at least equal to the nominal size of the device outlet. The discharge pipe shall terminate not more than 12 in (300 mm) above the floor. 
7.27.3 
An instantaneous-type (tankless) water heater, unless certified for installation on a combustible wall, shall be provided with appropriate protection as specified in Table 4.1. Such protection shall extend the full length and width of the heater and its draft hood.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
7.27.4 
Except where permitted by Clause 4.13.2, the minimum clearance from combustible material for an underfired storage-type water heater shall be 2 in (50 mm), and the minimum clearance for any other type of water heater shall be 6 in (150 mm). See also Clause 4.14.2. 
7.27.5 
Before installing an instantaneous-type (tankless) water heater, the installer shall ensure that there is sufficient water supply for proper operation of the heater.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
7.27.6 
Except for direct-vent water heaters, when the water heater is used in a combo heating system, return-air inlets shall not be installed in the same enclosure that contains both an air-handling unit and the water heater. Adequate combustion air shall be provided for the water heater. 
7.27.7 
When the return air duct( s) of an air handling unit in a combo heating system is installed in an enclosure in which any spillage-susceptible appliances are located, it shall be sealed to the air handling unit casing, and joints in the ducting shall be sealed to prevent infiltration of air from the enclosure into the return-air ducting.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
Section 8-Venting Systems and Air Supply for Appliances 
8.1 General 
8.1.1 
The requirements of Clause 8.2 shall apply to central-heating furnaces, boilers, and hot-water heaters. 
8.1.2 
The requirements of Clauses 8.2 to 8.5 shall not apply to a direct-vent appliance. 
Note: Regardless of the category type, when an appliance utilizes indoor combustion air, it is not considered a direct-vent appliance.

8.2 
Air-supply determination for central-heating furnaces, boilers, and hot-water heaters 
8.2.3 
An outdoor air supply shall not be required for a single water heater with an input of 50 000 Btuh (15 kW) or less within an enclosure or structure where there are no other appliances that require an air supply. Except for direct-vent water heaters, when the water heater is contained in an enclosure, permanent openings shall be provided as described in Clause 8.2.6.
Chapter 1-Water Heaters
8.2.6 
When an appliance(s) is located within an enclosure and permanent openings sized and located in accordance with Items (a) and (b) of this Clause are supplied to allow communication between the enclosure and the rest of the structure, the total volume of the structure may be used to determine air supply requirements, provided that the structure is not constructed as described in Clause 8.2.l(a) and does not comply with Clause 8.2.l(b). Otherwise, the volume of the enclosure shall be used. The openings shall be as follows:

(a)	In all cases, an opening shall be provided that shall
(i)	have a free area of not less than 1 in2 per 1000 Btuh (2225 mm2 per 	kW) of the total input of all appliances within the enclosure; and
(ii)	be located not more than 18 in ( 450 mm) or less than 6 in (150 mm) 	above floor level.
(b)	When one or more appliances are equipped with draft-control devices, 	an additional opening shall be supplied having the same free area as 	the opening required in Item (a), and the opening shall be located as 	near the ceiling as practicable, but in no case lower than the relief 	opening of the lowest draft-control device.

The National Plumbing Code of Canada (2010) specifies the requirements for hot water tank installations. The two areas of most concern to gas technicians/fitters are those dealing with shut-off valves and relief valves. Read and understand the most updated edition and printing with erratum of the National Plumbing Code of Canada for all requirements.

Chapter 1-Water Heaters

Additional requirements and recommendations for gas-fired water heater installations can be found in manufacturer's instructions, manuals and service bulletins.

Compliance with manufacturer's recommendations and instructions is a code requirement and is necessary for safe and efficient water heater installation and servicing.

•	Operating and troubleshooting instructions

Types of Water Heaters 
Water Heaters 
Water heaters form the largest class of gas appliances. Their popularity is due to low initial cost, low operating cost, cleanliness and convenience. Water heaters range in size from very small recreational vehicle units, to domestic sizes for residential use, to larger installations for commercial buildings and manufacturing processes.

The most common type of water heater used for residential service and low-demand commercial applications is the direct-fired storage heater.
